security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only Markdown guidance and YAML templates for API design. No executable code, no file system access beyond its own directory, no network calls, no code execution capabilities. This is a prompt-based knowledge module with zero attack surface.

content.user_title: Design REST, GraphQL, and gRPC APIs
content.value_statement: APIs often suffer from inconsistent patterns and poor documentation. This framework provides proven design patterns, error handling conventions, and ready-to-use OpenAPI and AsyncAPI templates. Build developer-friendly APIs that scale.
actual_capabilities: Design REST APIs following HTTP best practices and status code conventions
Create GraphQL schemas with connection patterns and mutation input types
Define gRPC services with protobuf message structures
Write OpenAPI 3.1 and AsyncAPI 3.0 specifications from templates
Implement API versioning strategies for backward compatibility
Design pagination, filtering, and rate limiting patterns
limitations: Does not generate implementation code or server stubs
Does not validate existing API specifications
Does not test API endpoints or generate test cases
Does not deploy or monitor APIs in production

prompt_templates.title: Basic REST Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a REST API for user management. Include endpoints for listing users with pagination, creating users, updating profiles, and deleting accounts. Show proper status codes and error response format.

prompt_templates.title: GraphQL Schema
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a GraphQL mutation for creating an order. Include the input type, payload type with error handling, and show how to return field-level validation errors.

prompt_templates.title: gRPC Definition
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a protobuf definition for a payment service. Include streaming support for real-time transaction updates and use appropriate gRPC status codes for error handling.

prompt_templates.title: API Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate an OpenAPI 3.1 specification for an e-commerce API. Include authentication with Bearer tokens, rate limiting headers, and comprehensive error responses with examples.

output_examples.input: Design a REST API for a todo list application
output: GET /todos - List all todos with pagination and filtering by status
POST /todos - Create a new todo item with title and optional description
GET /todos/{id} - Retrieve a specific todo item
201 Created returns Location header with todo URL
422 Unprocessable Entity for validation errors with field-level details

best_practices: Use plural nouns for resources and kebab-case for multi-word paths like /shopping-carts
Return appropriate HTTP status codes: 201 for creation, 204 for successful deletion with no content
Include pagination with cursor or offset-based pagination and include total counts
Design error responses with machine-readable codes and human-readable messages
anti_patterns: Using verbs in URLs like /getUsers or /createTodo - use HTTP methods instead
Ignoring HTTP semantics by using POST for all operations
Returning generic 500 errors without request IDs for debugging
Exposing internal database fields directly in API responses

faq.question: What API styles does this skill support?
faq.answer: REST, GraphQL, and gRPC with dedicated guidance and templates for each approach.

faq.question: What is the recommended versioning strategy?
faq.answer: URI versioning like /api/v1/users is recommended for public APIs for visibility and cache-friendliness.

faq.question: How does this integrate with AI agents?
faq.answer: Agents reference this skill when designing APIs to apply consistent patterns and generate OpenAPI specs.

faq.question: Does this skill store any data?
faq.answer: No. This is a read-only knowledge skill containing documentation and templates only.

faq.question: Why use cursor-based pagination?
faq.answer: Cursor pagination provides consistent results even when data changes during pagination and works better for real-time data.

faq.question: How is this different from code generation tools?
faq.answer: This focuses on API design patterns and documentation. It does not generate implementation code or server stubs.
